metadata.title: PSI to kPa Converter – Trusted Pressure Translation
metadata.description: Convert pounds per square inch to kilopascals with NIST-backed constants, calibration reminders, and safety cues for cylinders, HVAC, labs, and recipes.

fields.label: Pressure in PSI
fields.help_text: Enter your gauge reading; negative values are blocked. For vacuum/absolute work, adjust for atmospheric pressure separately.

introduction: Enter PSI and get kilopascals instantly using the NIST-aligned factor so mechanics, lab staff, and cooks can trust the number.
The interface stays lean while surfacing calibration and gauge-limit reminders for cylinders, HVAC, lab protocols, and pressure-cooker recipes.
Safety cues point you back to manufacturer specs and OSHA/ISO guidance whenever pressures approach regulated ranges.
methodology: We multiply PSI by 6.894757293, the NIST-recognized constant derived from the SI pascal definition (1 kPa = 100,000 Pa) and the inch-pound PSI definition.
The factor is linear and reversible: 1 kPa = 0.1450377377 psi. Internal math keeps full precision; rounding is for display.
Gauge vs absolute: the numeric factor is the same, but your reference changes. Note whether your instrument reports gauge or absolute and adjust for atmospheric pressure when needed.
examples: 35 psi converts to 241.32 kPa, matching common passenger car tire placards.
15 psi converts to 103.42 kPa for autoclave or recipe setpoints.
2000 psi converts to 13,789.51 kPa for industrial cylinders and hydraulic checks.

faqs.question: Why this factor?
faqs.answer: It is the NIST-backed ratio linking PSI and kPa. Using the exact factor keeps conversions reversible and consistent with engineering handbooks and university fluid mechanics courses.

faqs.question: Is this suitable for compliance?
faqs.answer: Use it as a reference. Pair the converted number with your gauge’s calibration tolerance and follow OSHA/ISO documentation for regulated equipment.

faqs.question: How do I handle vacuum readings?
faqs.answer: This tool blocks negative inputs because it assumes gauge pressure. For absolute or vacuum measurements, use a tool designed for absolute pressure and adjust for ambient conditions.

faqs.question: Can I convert back to PSI?
faqs.answer: Yes. Multiply kPa by 0.1450377377 or use the PSI ⇄ kPa swap in the companion converter.

glossary.definition: A US customary pressure unit equal to one pound-force over one square inch, common in automotive and industrial settings.
A metric pressure unit equal to 1,000 pascals, widely used in engineering, HVAC, and laboratory measurements.
The allowable deviation between an instrument reading and a reference standard; required for compliance and QA.
